title: 107_hr2645
content: The Motor Donor Act, also known as the National Organ Donor Registry, amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a National Organ Donor Registry. The purposes of this subpart are to increase organ and tissue donor registrations, enhance information on donation, ensure accurate information on individual wishes, and provide grants for state donor registries. The subpart aims to boost organ and tissue donor registrations by providing grants to states for establishing donor registries through driver's license applications and linking them to the National Registry. The Registry, maintained by the Secretary, will contain information on individuals expressing intent to donate. The Motor Donor Act establishes a national organ and tissue donor registry called the `Registry', consisting of individual information like name, address, date of birth, and a unique identification number. The Secretary will coordinate with states and organ procurement organizations during an initial 2-year period after enactment to boost donor registrations. During the 2-year period after the Motor Donor Act's enactment, the Secretary will coordinate with states to share data with existing organ donor registries and provide ongoing links. In the initial 4-year period, activities will be coordinated to promote the establishment of organ donor registries through the driver's license process. The Secretary will also work with organ procurement organizations. The Motor Donor Act aims to promote organ and tissue donor registries through the driver's license process. Organ procurement organizations will have 24-hour access to the Registry with a designated password. The Secretary will also disseminate information to all U.S. citizens through a website within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Motor Donor Act requires the Secretary to disseminate information about organ and tissue donations to U.S. citizens through a website within 3 years of enactment. Individuals can elect to participate in the Registry through the website, and will be notified of their participation within 4 months. The Registry allows individuals to indicate their intent to serve as organ or tissue donors. Participation does not impact organ allocation or legally bind consent, except as provided by State law. Individuals can request to cancel their participation. The Registry allows individuals to indicate their intent to serve as organ or tissue donors. Participation does not legally bind consent, except as provided by State law. Individuals can request to cancel their participation at any time. The Secretary will promptly remove information of those who cancel from the Registry. The Secretary can award grants to States for planning and implementing State programs. The Secretary can award grants to States for planning and implementing State registries associated with the driver's license application process and linkages with the Registry. States must submit applications demonstrating procedures for individual participation. Each state must establish procedures for individuals to make legally binding gifts for organ and tissue donation when applying for a driver's license. The procedures must comply with specific requirements outlined by the Secretary. The State procedures for driver's license applications must include an option for individuals to designate their intent to be an organ and tissue donor. The application must contain a question asking if the individual wishes to be an organ donor. The State procedures for driver's license applications must include a question asking if the individual wishes to have their organ donor designation noted in the State registry or on their driver's license if they answer affirmatively. The State procedures require individuals to indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license or in the State registry. Information must be forwarded to the Registry within 100 days of designation, including any changes in designation or address. The State procedures mandate individuals to indicate their organ donor preference on their driver's license or in the State registry. Any changes in designation or address information must be forwarded to the Registry. Individuals who choose not to have their organ donor designation included will not have their information forwarded. Access to information by organ procurement organizations is also outlined in the State procedures. The State procedures require individuals to indicate their organ donor preference, with information recorded in the individual's computer record for 24-hour access by organ procurement organizations without any fees. Priority in grant awards is given to States collaborating on organ donation programs. The Secretary gives priority in awarding grants to States collaborating with organ procurement organizations. Grants awarded under this subsection cannot exceed $300,000. An advisory task force on organ and tissue donation, consisting of 5 members appointed by the Secretary, is established. The Task Force on organ and tissue donation consists of 5 members appointed by the Secretary based on their experience in organ donations, procurement, or transplants. At least 1 member must be a physician with transplant experience, and another member must have organ procurement experience. At least 1 member of the Task Force must be a physician experienced in organ transplants, and another member must have experience in organ procurement. Members serve a 3-year term, with staggered terms for initial members. Vacancies in the Task Force are filled as needed. The Task Force members serve staggered 3-year terms, with vacancies filled as needed. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and must submit a report within 1 year. The Task Force partners with the Coalition on Donation for a national awareness campaign and conducts a study to improve the Registry and increase public awareness about organ and tissue donation. Members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Task Force members do not receive compensation but are allowed travel expenses for their services. The Task Force members do not receive compensation but may provide voluntary and uncompensated services. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Task Force without reimbursement. The Department of Health and Human Services will provide administrative support. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Health and Human Services will provide administrative support to the Task Force. The Task Force is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. "Subpart 2--Organ Procurement. Amendment of Internal Revenue Code." Section 6103(m) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow disclosure of taxpayer identification information to the Department of Health and Human Services for organ donor program purposes. The Department of Health and Human Services can only use disclosed information for contacting individuals about the national organ and tissue donor registry. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Subpart 2 of part H of title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended in sections 374(a), 374(d), 375(1), and 378 by replacing "this part" with "this subpart".
